parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Implementing crop rotation, particularly with the inclusion of legumes, led to an increase in soil organic matter.
[Statement 2]: Crop rotation, especially with legumes, increased soil organic carbon.
[Statement 3]: Longer crop rotations could result in lower levels of soil organic matter.
[Statement 4]: The studies on crop rotation and soil organic matter covered a range of soil types, including clay, loam, and sandy soils.

key: _gemini-2-5-pro__What actions can be taken to increase soil organic matter on agricultural land?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: A higher diversity of soil invertebrates and microorganisms is found in low-input systems.
[Statement 2]: Adding mulch to crops increases soil animal and fungal numbers, diversity and activity.
[Statement 3]: Higher numbers, diversity, functional diversity or activity of soil organisms are found under organic management.

key: _gemini-2-5-pro__Which actions are most beneficial for increasing the diversity of soil organisms?
_gemini-2-5-pro__What are the effects of amending soil with different types of organic materials?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Amending the soil with a mix of manure and inorganic fertilizers increases microbial biomass and activity.
[Statement 2]: Amending the soil with a mix of manure and inorganic fertilizers increases microbial diversity.
[Statement 3]: The addition of crop remains and straw has been shown to increase microbial biomass.
[Statement 4]: Mixed amendments were more effective at reducing the size of cracks in dry soil compared to inorganic fertilizers alone or no fertilizer.
[Statement 5]: Incorporating straw has been found to improve soil structure.
[Statement 6]: Incorporating straw may not be effective in compacted, anaerobic soils.
[Statement 7]: Straw addition can reduce soil loss.
[Statement 8]: The effects of straw addition on soil loss can be mixed depending on the soil type.
[Statement 9]: Soils with mixed fertilizers and manure alone have been found to contain more organic carbon.
[Statement 10]: The incorporation of plant material into the soil has been shown to increase carbon levels.
[Statement 11]: The incorporation of plant material into the soil can lead to larger soil aggregates.
[Statement 12]: Soils with manure and inorganic fertilizers have been found to have more nutrients.
[Statement 13]: One study showed inconsistent effects of manure and inorganic fertilizers on soil nutrients.
[Statement 14]: The application of compost or straw has been associated with higher soil nitrogen levels.
[Statement 15]: The effects of processed wastes on soil nitrogen levels have been mixed.
[Statement 16]: The incorporation of straw has been shown to reduce nitrate leaching.
[Statement 17]: Mixed manure and inorganic fertilizer amendments have been found to increase maize yield.
[Statement 18]: The incorporation of straw has been linked to higher barley yield.
[Statement 19]: The incorporation of crop remains earlier in the season has been found to increase grain yields.

[Statement 1]: Reducing grazing intensity can help to reduce soil erosion.
[Statement 2]: Reducing grazing time in forage crops can lead to less sediment erosion.
[Statement 3]: Amending the soil with a mix of organic and inorganic amendments is more effective at reducing the size of cracks in dry soil than using inorganic fertilizers alone or no fertilizer.
[Statement 4]: Changing tillage practices can have an impact on soil erosion.
[Statement 5]: Reduced tillage can result in reduced soil loss and runoff compared to conventional ploughing.
[Statement 6]: No-tillage can increase soil loss in the absence of crop cover.
[Statement 7]: Some trials have shown no differences between tillage systems in terms of soil loss.
[Statement 8]: Across-slope cultivation can reduce soil loss compared to up-and-downslope cultivation.

key: _gemini-2-5-pro__Besides retaining crop residues, what other actions can reduce soil erosion on agricultural land with clay soils?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Two controlled, randomized, replicated trials in China on mixed manure and inorganic fertilizer amendments found increased maize yields.
[Statement 2]: In the Philippines, one trial found that incorporating crop remains earlier in the season resulted in higher grain yields.
[Statement 3]: Three randomized, replicated, controlled studies on amending soils with plant remains that produce weed-controlling chemicals found positive, negative, and mixed effects on yield when compared to weeded controls.
[Statement 4]: When compared to unweeded controls, two studies on amending soils with plant remains that produce weed-controlling chemicals found positive effects on yield.
[Statement 5]: When compared to unweeded controls, one study on amending soils with plant remains that produce weed-controlling chemicals found mixed effects on yield depending on the crop.

key: _gemini-2-5-pro__What does the evidence say about the effectiveness of different soil amendments for improving crop yields on farms in Asia?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Based on actions taken to reduce nutrient loss from agricultural soils, several key messages can be highlighted.
[Statement 2]: Applying formulated chemical compounds, such as nitrification inhibitors, was found to reduce nitrate losses.
[Statement 3]: The use of manures and agricultural composts has shown mixed results.
[Statement 4]: Applying farmyard or poultry manure can reduce nutrient loss.
[Statement 5]: Applying farmyard or poultry manure in winter rather than autumn was more effective.
[Statement 6]: The practice of applying manure and compost could lead to higher nitrate leaching.
[Statement 7]: High rates of cotton gin compost and poultry manure can cause increased nutrient loss.
[Statement 8]: The addition of molasses was found to improve nutrient retention.
[Statement 9]: Changing tillage practices can impact nutrient retention.
[Statement 10]: Reduced tillage led to higher nutrient retention.
[Statement 11]: Conventionally tilled soil lost more carbon and nitrate compared to no-till soil.
[Statement 12]: Managing grazing intensity can play a role in nutrient loss.
[Statement 13]: Excluding grazing animals increased soil carbon and nitrogen.
[Statement 14]: Reducing grazing time lowered phosphate levels and sediment erosion.

key: _gemini-2-5-pro__What actions can be taken to reduce nutrient loss, specifically nitrates, from agricultural soils?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Adding mulch to crops increased soil animal and fungal numbers, diversity and activity.
[Statement 2]: Mulch improved soil structure and increased soil organic matter.
[Statement 3]: Growing cover crops resulted in more diverse nematode communities.
[Statement 4]: A study found greater microbial biomass under ryegrass compared to a ryegrass/vetch cover crop mix.
[Statement 5]: Increased soil carbon levels were found under cover crops.
[Statement 6]: Soil carbon levels increased further when legumes were included in cover crops.
[Statement 7]: Four studies in Asia, Europe, and the USA found higher numbers, diversity, functional diversity or activity of soil organisms under organic management.
[Statement 8]: Organically managed orchards had higher soil carbon levels compared to conventionally managed orchards.
[Statement 9]: One trial found soil carbon was lower under organic management compared to alley cropping.

key: _gemini-2-5-pro__Which actions are most consistently beneficial for both increasing soil organic carbon and improving biodiversity?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Amending the soil with fresh plant material and crop remains can improve the soil structure of silty-clay soils.
[Statement 2]: Incorporating straw improved soil structure.
[Statement 3]: Adding high rates of cotton gin compost and poultry manure improved soil structure and reduced soil loss.
[Statement 4]: Including forage crops in crop rotations has been found to reduce rainwater runoff and soil loss.
[Statement 5]: Including legumes in crop rotations can increase water infiltration.
[Statement 6]: Using crop rotation with legumes has been shown to increase soil organic carbon.
[Statement 7]: Using crop rotation with legumes has been shown to increase soil organic matter.

_gemini-2-5-pro__As an alternative to using chemical fertilizers to increase crop yield, what organic soil management practices are shown to be effective?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Two controlled, randomized, replicated studies from India and Pakistan found that growing green manures led to increased grain yields.
[Statement 2]: One replicated trial in Canada found lower yields in organically managed soils.
[Statement 3]: Two replicated trials in the USA reported mixed effects on yield.
[Statement 4]: One replicated study from Canada showed lower yields under minimum or no-tillage systems compared to conventional tillage.
[Statement 5]: A study found that crop yields increased under no-tillage.

[Statement 1]: Compacted soils recovered when sheep were excluded for 2.5 years.
[Statement 2]: Excluding grazing animals increased soil carbon and nitrogen.
[Statement 3]: Reducing grazing time in forage crops led to higher soil phosphate levels.
[Statement 4]: Reducing grazing time in forage crops led to less sediment erosion.

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Five controlled trials from China and India have addressed the effects of soil amendments on biodiversity in soils including sandy loam texture.
[Statement 2]: One study from Japan has addressed the effects of soil amendments on biodiversity in soils including sandy loam texture.
[Statement 3]: One randomized, replicated experiment from Belgium has addressed the effects of soil amendments on biodiversity in soils including sandy loam texture.
[Statement 4]: In soils with a mix of manure and inorganic fertilizers, there was higher microbial biomass and activity.

[Statement 6]: Manure alone increased microbial biomass.
[Statement 7]: The addition of crop remains and straw was found to increase microbial biomass.

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Amending the soil with bacteria or fungi can increase soil organic matter content.
[Statement 2]: Conventional ploughing and sub-soiling can increase the ability of soil to absorb water.
[Statement 3]: Conventional ploughing and sub-soiling can increase soil water content.
[Statement 4]: Organically managed orchards have been shown to have higher soil carbon levels.
[Statement 5]: Reducing the use of fertilizers, pesticides, or herbicides can lead to a higher diversity of soil invertebrates and microorganisms.

key: _gemini-2-5-pro__As an alternative to adding mulch, what actions can improve soil moisture and drought resilience on sandy soils?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Amending soils with manures and agricultural composts can have several effects on soil health.
[Statement 2]: The application of manure or compost has been found to increase microbial biomass.
[Statement 3]: Poultry manure specifically has been shown to increase microbial respiration.
[Statement 4]: High rates of cotton gin compost and poultry manure have improved soil structure and reduced soil loss.
[Statement 5]: Lower soil loss and runoff have been noted when manure was used with other treatments.
[Statement 6]: Manure and compost application has been linked to higher organic matter, larger soil aggregations, and improved physical properties.
[Statement 7]: Farmyard or poultry manure application has been reported to reduce nutrient loss and lead to higher nitrogen levels.
[Statement 8]: High application rates of cotton gin compost and poultry manure have been found to increase nutrient loss.
[Statement 9]: Higher nitrate leaching has been observed after amending soils with some animal-derived products.
[Statement 10]: The timing of application can be a factor in nutrient loss.
[Statement 11]: Applying farmyard manure in winter instead of autumn can lead to lower nutrient loss.
[Statement 12]: Soil organic carbon and matter can be affected by amending soils with animal-derived products.
[Statement 13]: Higher carbon levels have been found after manure application.
[Statement 14]: Manure and compost application has been reported to increase organic matter.
[Statement 15]: Some studies found no change in organic matter levels from manure application.
[Statement 16]: Applying manures or composts can lead to higher crop yields.

key: _gemini-2-5-pro__What are the wider soil health effects of amending soils with animal-derived products like manure or composts?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Thirteen studies evaluated the effects of converting to organic farming on butterflies and moths.
[Statement 2]: Seven studies found that organic arable farms had a greater species richness and abundance of butterflies and moths than conventionally managed farms.
[Statement 3]: One study found that butterfly abundance increased with the time since conversion to organic management.
[Statement 4]: Four studies found that organic farms had a similar species richness and abundance of macro-moths and butterflies to conventionally managed farms.
[Statement 5]: Two studies found that both organic and conventional farms in a landscape with a high proportion of organic farms had higher species richness of butterflies and burnet moths than farms in a landscape with a high proportion of conventional farms.
[Statement 6]: A before-and-after study in the UK found that after a mixed farm converted to organic management, the species richness and total abundance of large moths increased.
[Statement 7]: A before-and-after study in the UK found that after a mixed farm converted to organic management, the abundance of two butterfly species decreased.
[Statement 8]: No studies were found that evaluated the effects of converting to organic agriculture or aquaculture near peatlands on peatland vegetation.

key: _gemini-2-5-pro__What are the documented benefits and drawbacks of converting to low-input or organic farming systems?
_gemini-2-5-pro__In Europe, what alternatives to conventional ploughing can improve soil structure?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Changing tillage practices is an alternative to conventional ploughing that can improve soil structure.
[Statement 2]: Reduced tillage can maintain or increase soil organic matter.
[Statement 3]: Reduced tillage can improve soil structure.
[Statement 4]: Reduced tillage can lead to more microbes and earthworms.
[Statement 5]: Reduced tillage can lead to higher soil organic carbon.

[Statement 1]: A controlled, randomized, replicated trial in Italy found that applying a high rate of compost increased soil organic matter levels.
[Statement 2]: A controlled, randomized, replicated trial in Italy found that applying a high rate of compost increased microbial biomass.
[Statement 3]: A controlled, randomized, replicated trial in Italy found that applying a high rate of compost increased fruit yield.
[Statement 4]: Eleven replicated, randomized, controlled studies from Italy, Spain, and the USA found more microbial biomass in soils with reduced tillage, compared to conventional tillage, in some comparisons.
[Statement 5]: Two replicated, randomized, controlled studies from Spain and Syria found less microbial biomass in soils with reduced tillage in some comparisons.
[Statement 6]: Two replicated, randomized, controlled studies from Spain found similar amounts of microbial biomass in soils with reduced tillage in some comparisons.
[Statement 7]: One replicated, controlled study from Italy found more microbial biomass in soils with crop rotations compared to continuous crops in some comparisons.
[Statement 8]: One replicated, randomized, controlled study from Spain found less microbial biomass in soils with crop rotations in some comparisons.
[Statement 9]: One replicated, randomized, controlled study from Portugal found more fungi in soils with crop rotations compared to continuous crops.
[Statement 10]: One replicated, randomized, controlled study from Portugal found similar amounts of bacteria in soils with crop rotations compared to continuous crops.

key: _gemini-2-5-pro__Which actions are most effective for increasing soil microbial biomass?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Planting or maintaining ground cover in orchards or vineyards can be effective for reducing soil erosion.
[Statement 2]: Studies found less erosion in soils with ground cover compared to bare or tilled soils.
[Statement 3]: One study found that permanent cover crops resulted in the least erosion.
[Statement 4]: Adding mulch to crops increased soil stability.
[Statement 5]: Adding mulch to crops reduced soil erosion and runoff.
[Statement 6]: Growing cover crops, either beneath the main crop or between crop rows, has been shown to be effective at reducing erosion.
[Statement 7]: One study showed the highest soil stability under a grass cover.
[Statement 8]: Retaining crop residues reduced water runoff and soil erosion.
[Statement 9]: Planting new hedges led to reduced soil erosion.
[Statement 10]: Less sediment erosion was observed when grazing time was reduced.
[Statement 11]: Amending the soil with non-chemical minerals and mineral wastes can reduce erosion.
[Statement 12]: The evidence for the effect of adding sewage sludge on soil erosion is mixed.
[Statement 13]: One study found that adding sewage sludge led to less erosion.
[Statement 14]: One study found no difference in soil stability after adding sewage sludge.
[Statement 15]: One study on planting hedgerows found no significant difference in soil particle sizes between soils with or without them.
[Statement 16]: Planting hedgerows may not be a primary method for erosion control.

key: _gemini-2-5-pro__What are some of the most effective actions for reducing soil erosion on agricultural land?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Amending soil with municipal wastes or composts from municipal wastes can reduce soil loss and water runoff.
[Statement 2]: One study found mixed results when composts and municipal wastes were added to soil.
[Statement 3]: The application of manures and agricultural composts has been shown to increase microbial biomass.
[Statement 4]: The application of manures and agricultural composts has been shown to reduce soil loss and water runoff.
[Statement 5]: The application of manures and agricultural composts has been shown to result in higher crop yields.
[Statement 6]: Some studies found applying manures and agricultural composts reduced nutrient loss.
[Statement 7]: Some studies found applying manures and agricultural composts led to higher nitrogen levels in the soil.
[Statement 8]: Some studies found applying manures and agricultural composts increased soil organic carbon and organic matter.
[Statement 9]: One study found that manure application led to higher nitrate leaching.
[Statement 10]: Two studies showed that manure application had no effect on organic matter levels.
[Statement 11]: When a mix of organic and inorganic amendments is used, benefits can include higher microbial biomass and activity.
[Statement 12]: Using a mix of organic and inorganic amendments can reduce soil erosion.
[Statement 13]: Using a mix of organic and inorganic amendments can increase soil organic carbon.
[Statement 14]: Using a mix of organic and inorganic amendments can result in higher crop yields.
[Statement 15]: One study found inconsistent effects on soil nutrients when using a mix of manure and inorganic fertilizers.

key: _gemini-2-5-pro__On agricultural land, what are the documented benefits and drawbacks of amending soil with manures or municipal wastes?
_gemini-2-5-pro__What actions are available to improve the physical structure of clay and clay-loam soils?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Amending the soil with fresh plant material or crop remains may improve the soil structure.
[Statement 2]: Incorporating straw can improve soil structure.
[Statement 3]: Incorporating straw can result in larger soil aggregates.
[Statement 4]: The addition of organic processing wastes or their composts, such as cotton gin compost and poultry manure, can enhance soil structure.
[Statement 5]: Including legumes in crop rotations has been shown to increase water infiltration.
[Statement 6]: One study found that including legumes in crop rotations had no effect on soil particle size.
